title: Proposed change to ranked bans. Each player picks one.
body:
It's been many years since League was released back in 2009, and many changes have come before it.

But one factor that has been a constant is the ranked system's banning phase. 1 player on your team is chosen to ban 3 champions. It was fine back then, but problems exist now and such a system leaves a bitter taste.

First of all, we need to address the ban amount. Why is it limited to 3 per team? It was back in 2012 when people started asking for a 4th ban, and with reason.

6/123 champions. Don't you think that's a tad small? There are around 20 current champions which are considered the problem children, so why let 14 instances of "unhealthy" champions get past the gates?

For the first change, we need to increase this number to 10. 5 bans for team. Sure some unhealthy champions are still getting passed, but at least you're able to limit to better to what can be counterpicked more easily. But, we can't let this be put in the hands of a single player.

Why is it that one person decides the bans? Why is it that one person decides which champions your team might be facing against?

The issue with this is that you're putting faith into 1 person knowing who/what to ban that would be optimal for your team. And in truth it just doesn't work out. The bans shouldn't be determined by 1 person, it should be determined by everyone on your team. After all, it is a team game.

Instead of just throwing them all at one person and hoping they do good, we give each player a ban. One by one everyone will decide who to ban. Everyone can get rid of a champion they wont feel comfortable playing against. Everyone can feel like they're being a part of the team.

Everything is always worse when everything depends on one person in a game that is supposed to be a team game.

The only time Yasuo is an issue is if they pick a champ with good knockup potential for him to work with.  Otherwise, there are plenty of good counterpicks to him in lane.  Malz and Karthus come to mind.  Kayle does well too.  None of them are really meta, but they work, and are quite powerful when used correctly.

I think double crit is a bit dumb.  +50% crit would be better, and would still force actual crit investment, as opposed to just building shiv and critting 50%.  Wind wall needs some kind of limit on it.  50% bonus armor pen is dumb.  These things are all tuneable though.  The big issue is that he gets considerably stronger with champs that synergize with him, in fact, he's dependent on those champs for success in most cases.  This causes him to either suck, or be massively overpowered, cause you can't do anything to deal with him if malph gets a 3 man ult and yasuo takes his free ticket in to kill 3 people, and mop up the remaining two.

It's not that I think he's brokenly overpowered (anymore), but I do think that he remains to be _conceptually_ broken and horribly designed. 

 I also get that he's easy to kill, whatever, but the fact that he has all these free stats packed into his kit, and watching him **woosh, woosh, woosh, woosh, woosh** all over the place with an expandable fart wall that blocks all projectiles, in addition to an ult that procs ON THINGS THAT AREN'T ACTUALLY KNOCKUPS, it makes me want to gouge my eyes out with a spoon watching him in lane.  His kit is obnoxious and has never been fun or engaging to go against. 

I feel the same way about Kalista - from my perspective, neither of them are champions to me.  I simply cannot accept that anything that toxic should be allowed to exist on the roster.

I get that you were being sarcastic, but you're right.  We were relatively better when we first started ranked.  Because there were fewer champions.  The burden of knowledge required for an individual player to consistently perform well in ranked  was lower, so by comparison, new players in ranked now are further below that burden than any of us were.  This is a particularly egregious burden to put on them if they are first pick, when they are expected to ban 3 champions without having the knowledge necessary to do so.

A concern is would it then stop at four or five bans or would the next handful of champions in line just be the new OP that we need more bans for?

Clever idea, but all this does is take away from the "team" aspect of the game. It makes it more of a selfish, "Who can I ban to help myself?" type situation. It will also increase the amount of people who say "Well, I banned Riven so I'm going top. I don't care if I'm last pick."

More bans would be good, but I think 5 is too much. 4 would be sufficient. I also think that this system would only increase toxicity, but who knows?

In solo queue, you need to rely on yourself first, and your team second. In ranked teams, you can coordinate better. The current system allows the top player to use *all* of the bans in their favor. 

"Whoops, I can't stand playing against Fiora. Hmm...You know, Gnar is also difficult to deal with top lane. Buut then again, I also really don't like playing against the new Sion." 

At least a system where everyone gets one ban each requires people to talk and share their ideas for strategy, and gives everyone a fair chance at helping to shape their lane.

And to address the "Well, I banned Riven so I'm going top. I don't care if I'm last pick." That kind of player is going to do whatever they want anyway, regardless of what other players want. It doesn't matter whether you give them power or not, Riot already has made their stance clear. Those players eventually get punished anyway, especially in ranked.
